ABOUT.ABOUT_ME:
Hi! My name is Irene, and I’m a senior graphic designer specialized in branding. Design has always been part of my life: growing up in a print shop surrounded by color swatches, the smell of ink, and stacks of paper… I had no other option. While trying to decode the secrets behind communication effectively through images, I decided to study audiovisuals and photography, and in this path I discovered that graphic design is my passion.

Everyone said “Everything is design”. Discovering the reasons behind an effective and visual interesting design, became my new mission/obsession.

CLARITY_AI.DESCRIPTION:
Collaborated with both the Marketing and Product Design teams in this B2B SaaS company, with key contributions including:

 - Applied UX measurements that improved navigation and increased leads and demo requests on the web app.
 - Created a style guide that fostered a design culture, reduced production times, and ensured visual consistency across all materials.
 - Enhanced data visualization for marketing and the web app by unifying their Design System, accelerating production and design workflows

CONCILIO_COMMS.DESCRIPTION:
Worked at this London-based Agency specialized in urban development and public consultations, with main responsibilities including:

 - Led the design team, providing expertise in client meetings, strengthening the agency’s professional perception, and accelerating design delivery, which increased project requests.
 - Designed powerful visual identities that unified communications, enhancing professionalism, recognition, and citizen engagement.

DIPUTACION_MALAGA.POSITION: Jefa de Comunicación Audiovisual - Área de Deportes, Diputación de Málaga
DIPUTACION_MALAGA.DESCRIPTION:
Part of the Sports Department’s communications office after an extracurricular internship, with main achievements including:

 - Professionalized the production of photography, video, and graphic design for sports events, improving public recognition.
 - Secured the success of the +deporte +mujer campaign by creating a visual identity that strengthened the relationship between the public institution and citizens

FREELANCE.DESCRIPTION: Freelance collaborations within the family business, producing product photography for advertising campaigns, large-format print design, editorial design, merchandising and signage.

HANSUKE_CONSULTING.DESCRIPTION: During COVID-19 I lLed the creation of the visual identity and marketing materials for their online annual conference, along with additional marketing collateral design for digital marketing campaigns as a freelancer.

UPL_VISION.DESCRIPTION: Worked freelance on graphic design for digital marketing and social media, as well as motion graphics, animation, and email marketing for UPL Design Agency, which mainly collaborates with brands in the personal care market.

WRANGLE.DESCRIPTION: As a freelance designer, I developed the visual identity of this start-up from the ground up, creating graphic materials for social media, editorial design, illustration, and print advertising.

1.TITLE: Graphic solutions for the real life
1.DESCRIPTION: Working with brands of different sizes has taught me that a solution only succeeds when it fits the client’s reality, their timing, resources and capabilities. My priority is to create design systems that clients can confidently use on their own, every day.

2.TITLE: Collaboration built on trust
2.DESCRIPTION: Good design relies on communication. I keep the process transparent, structured and free of last-minute surprises. This collaborative approach leads to results that feel genuinely aligned with the client and is often the reason relationships last well beyond the first project.

3.TITLE: Always building for what comes next
3.DESCRIPTION: Creativity requires constant curiosity, it´s a muscle that you should exercise in order to generate innovative and original concepts. I stay informed about new visual languages, tools and design trends, not as a checklist, but to understand how they can elevate a brand. The aim is to create work that feels current today while remaining relevant tomorrow.

HOW_I_WORK.TITLE: I am not interested in delivering something purely beautiful. I look for hidden opportunities, challenge assumptions and ensure every design has a purpose. The outcome is a solution that solves real problems while opening the door to new possibilities.

WHAT_I_DO.DESCRIPTION: Over the past five years, I have partnered with a wide range of organisations, from early-stage startups and public institutions to internationally focused companies. My work goes beyond making something look attractive. Design becomes a strategic tool that uncovers opportunities and delivers measurable impact.

BRAND_STRATEGY.4: Tone of voice and brand personality
BRAND_STRATEGY.TITLE: Brand Strategy
BRAND_STRATEGY.DESCRIPTION: I help brands understand where they stand, how they are perceived and where they can grow. By analysing market context and customer behaviour, I define strategies that strengthen competitive advantage and build long-term relevance. My role is to bring clarity and coherence to what a brand thinks, says and shows.

BRANDING.TITLE: Branding
BRANDING.DESCRIPTION: I collaborate closely with each client to translate their personality into visual identities that feel clear, memorable and practical to use. Through thoughtful art direction and flexible design systems, ideas evolve into brands with real presence in the market.

GRAPHIC_DESIGN.TITLE: Graphic Design
GRAPHIC_DESIGN.DESCRIPTION: Versatility has always been at the core of my work. I design across multiple disciplines so that brands can maintain consistency wherever they appear. The goal is simple: visuals that not only look good on their own, but operate as part of a coherent system.

UI/UX_DESIGN.TITLE: UI/UX Design
UI/UX_DESIGN.DESCRIPTION: I create digital experiences that balance brand expression, business goals and genuine user needs. My approach is grounded in research, data and usability, ensuring that every interaction feels intuitive and consistent.

CLARITY_AI.DESCRIPTION: Clarity AI is a leading sustainability technology platform that uses artificial intelligence to assess, analyse and report sustainability-related data. Its core mission is to enable investors, businesses and consumers to make informed decisions that contribute to a more sustainable future. The platform covers more than 70,000 companies, 430,000 funds and 400 national and sub-national governments, offering reliable data and methodologies grounded in scientific evidence.

CARD.TITLE: CLARITY AI
CARD.DESCRIPTION: Rebranding, UI/UX design, graphic design, editorial design and motion graphics

CLARITY_AI.WHEN_I_JOINED: When I joined Clarity AI, I realised that the brand lacked visual and narrative consistency, which limited its ability to evolve alongside the business. Without clear brand guidelines, visual output was inconsistent, and the tone of communication unintentionally positioned the company as an environmental NGO rather than a technology leader. To maximise impact, I defined three strategic priorities: a full brand refresh, improved data visualisation and a better user experience across the corporate website and the product.
CLARITY_AI.THE_VISUAL_ELEMENTS: Visual assets were scarce and limited to watercolour illustrations, which gave the brand an unintentionally naive appearance.
CLARITY_AI.I_REDESIGNED: I redesigned Clarity AI's visual identity to reflect its innovative vision and support its growth in the market. The result was a more modern and accessible visual universe (WCAG compliant), documented in a practical style guide that allowed the entire team to apply the brand consistently. To reinforce coherence and speed up production, I created templates, standardised visual assets and developed a shared library of icons and illustrations. This streamlined content creation and boosted brand recognition both internally and externally.
CLARITY_AI.I_DEVELOPED_GRAPHIC_STYLE: I also introduced a new illustration style based on the brand's primary colour, using abstract compositions to communicate key ideas. This illustration bank is now used across social media, the website and internal presentations. In addition, I curated a system of filtered stock photography, creating another layer of brand identification.
CLARITY_AI.AS_PART_OF_REBRANDING: As part of the rebrand, it became clear that the logotype required structural changes. It became difficult to read when scaled down, especially when placed alongside competitors' logos or printed in small formats. Since the brand wanted to keep the original concept, I refined the spacing and character shapes to improve legibility and performance at small sizes. For this reason, both versions of the logo appear throughout the project documentation.
CLARITY_AI.DATA_VISUALIZATION_DESCRIPTION: Although Clarity AI is a company driven by data and research, there was no solid approach to data visualisation. This made insights harder to communicate, particularly for non-technical audiences. One of my main challenges was to redesign the way data was presented across formats and platforms, making it clearer, more engaging and easier to understand.
CLARITY_AI.I_IDENTIFIED_STUDIES: Internal studies were perceived as technical and dense. My goal was to turn complexity into clarity. Through training workshops, I introduced new storytelling standards for teams working with clients, designed more appealing and interactive visualisations for the blog, and completely renewed print and digital research reports. As a result, information shifted from being a barrier to becoming a persuasive communication tool.
CLARITY_AI.CLARITY_PLATFORM_DATAVIZ: The Clarity AI platform included multiple, highly complex data modules, but lacked a unified system to ensure consistency and accessibility. Working closely with the UI/UX team, I designed a visualisation framework integrated into the Design System. This allowed teams to add new charts more easily, guaranteed accessibility and reduced development time by 50%, ensuring faster and more efficient implementation. The visualisations shown on the right form part of this Design System.
CLARITY_AI.UX_IMPROVEMENT_DESCRIPTION: As a visual designer at Clarity AI Design Product Team, I led the optimisation of both the corporate website and the data platform to enhance user experience, accessibility and conversion. With a data-driven approach and user-centred principles, I carried out a deep analysis of the user journey using heatmaps, confetti maps, scroll-maps and overlay reports. This allowed us to identify pain points in navigation and redesign the interface to align with the new brand identity, reduce conversion bottlenecks and increase both form submissions and traffic to the blog — an area that required high investment from the company.

BLOG_ISSUES.TITLE: Issues Identified in the Blog and Navigation
BLOG_ISSUES.TABS_CONFUSING: Some main issues included the presence of a long, confusing tab (Research & Insights) with no visual alignment with the rest of the site;
BLOG_ISSUES.CLICK_RATE: A low click-rate on the primary CTA "Request a Demo";
BLOG_ISSUES.FILTER_INCOHERENCE: Incoherent filtering options, offering only a single thematic filter despite broader options in the main menu, and no filtering at all on mobile;
BLOG_ISSUES.INFINITE_SCROLL: And infinite scrolling, which prevented users from reaching the bottom of the page or knowing how many results were available.

BLOG_SOLUTIONS.TITLE: Solutions Implemented
BLOG_SOLUTIONS.MENU_REORGANIZATION: I reorganised the main navigation menu to improve accessibility and create a more intuitive browsing experience.
BLOG_SOLUTIONS.CTA_REDESIGN: The main UX writing CTA was redesigned — both visually and verbally — to make it more compelling.
BLOG_SOLUTIONS.SEARCH_BAR: A keyword search bar was added, and filtering options were harmonised by including format and topic, with the possibility of selecting multiple filters simultaneously for a far more personalised experience.
BLOG_SOLUTIONS.SORT_RESULTS: I introduced the option to sort results by date or popularity
BLOG_SOLUTIONS.PAGINATION: Replaced infinite scroll with pagination, giving users full control over the content.
BLOG_SOLUTIONS.BLOG_REDESIGN: I also redesigned the entire blog template.

CLARITY_AI.TOGETHER_WITH_UIUX: Together with the UI/UX team, I rethought the waiting experience in the report-generation process. What was previously a moment of frustration became a moment of value: a clear progress bar and a small informative animation kept users informed and reassured, reinforcing the perception of efficiency and trust in the platform.

CARD.TITLE: FORMER TOOTING POLICE STATION
CARD.DESCRIPTION: Visual identity, graphic design, motion graphics and UI/UX design

TOOTING_POLICE_STATION.DESCRIPTION: Tooting Police Station is a former police building acquired by Telereal Trillium with the intention of transforming it into a residential development with shared community spaces, while preserving its historic structure and architectural character. At Concilio Communications, we created a contemporary visual identity tailored to the local audience, helping connect all consultation materials and build a sense of familiarity and trust with the residents of Tooting, London.
TOOTING_POLICE_STATION.CONTEXT_DESCRIPTION: Our research into the area revealed a young community with a strong emotional connection to local heritage, combined with a widespread feeling that landmarks such as the police station had been neglected over the years. This presented a clear opportunity. Rather than treating the building as a relic of the past, we could use design to celebrate its history in a fresh and approachable way, encouraging residents to participate in the consultation process.
TOOTING_POLICE_STATION.CONCEPT_STRATEGY_DESCRIPTION: We determined that the project needed a contemporary identity that felt relevant to a younger audience without losing its historic soul. A monochromatic palette offered simplicity and clear visual impact. The symbol was created using the building’s distinctive silhouette, which we were able to study in detail through drone imagery. Translating its outline into a graphic mark gave the brand a strong sense of place and immediate recognisability. To balance the length of the project name and strengthen the personality of the logo, the letters M, N and A were customised in line with the shape of the symbol. A flexible and eye-catching pattern was also developed to support both print and digital applications, helping the visual identity feel cohesive across all materials.
TOOTING_POLICE_STATION.FINAL_RESULT_DESCRIPTION: The branding was very positively received by the local community. The visual identity improved recognition of the project across the neighbourhood and helped increase participation in public consultations by 40% compared with previous initiatives. The designed materials sparked positive feedback on social media and local forums, where residents highlighted the emotional link between the graphic proposal and the history of the building. Ultimately, the brand positioned the development as a modern and inclusive initiative that respected collective memory while engaging directly with the residents of Tooting, London.

CARD.TITLE: CONCILIO COMMUNICATIONS
CARD.DESCRIPTION: Rebranding, UI/UX design, graphic design and editorial

CONCILIO_COMMS.DESCRIPTION: Concilio is a London-based communications consultancy specialising in the construction and property sector. The company acts as a bridge between developers and local communities, facilitating the statutory public consultations required for new urban developments. Through in-person events and online engagement, residents are able to share concerns, ask questions and influence decision-making, ensuring that regeneration projects are delivered in a more human, sustainable and participatory way.
CONCILIO_COMMS.CONTEXT_DESCRIPTION: After several months working within the company, it became clear that the existing visual system (rigid and slightly outdated) no longer reflected the organisation’s growth or evolving communication needs. Working closely with the leadership team, we rethought the brand structure to allow Concilio to expand its services without losing clarity or recognition. The result was a new three-part architecture: Concilio Consult, focused on public consultation and community engagement; Concilio Connect, dedicated to digital communication; and Concilio Create, a design studio specialising in branding, print and digital environments, which I had the opportunity to lead from its launch for two years.
CONCILIO_COMMS.CONCEPT_STRATEGY_DESCRIPTION: To distinguish these three areas while maintaining a unified brand, I proposed a system of sub-brands. Concilio enjoys high recognition within the sector, so it was strategically important not to stray too far from the existing logotype. Radically redesigning it risked creating confusion or giving the impression of a new, unrelated company. Instead, we retained the original structure of the logo and added the service identifier in the same typeface, creating a clear, consistent and scalable system that supported future growth.
CONCILIO_COMMS.FINAL_RESULT_DESCRIPTION: The introduction of Concilio Create and Concilio Connect led to a significant increase in project volume. Clients valued the ability to access an end-to-end service: from stakeholder engagement and community consultation, to website design and full visual identity development for each project. This integrated approach streamlined processes, saved time, and gave clients a competitive advantage, presenting their developments with a more professional, coherent and impactful image. Some of the projects delivered under this new structure included Dagenham Green, Tooting Police Station and Bakers Building.

DAGENHAM.DESCRIPTION: Peabody is one of London’s largest housing associations. A few years ago, the organisation acquired a former stamping plant in Dagenham, East London. The site was renamed Dagenham Green, with plans to deliver more than 3,500 new homes, including 1,550 affordable units, as well as a secondary school, local shops, restaurants and a public park featuring native vegetation.
DAGENHAM.INTUITION_AND_RESOLVE_DESCRIPTION: This was one of the first projects I led with Concilio Create, and the main challenge was not only designing the consultation materials, but redefining how we worked as a team. Drawing inspiration from Design Thinking methodologies, I proposed a more collaborative workflow from the earliest stages. All key stakeholders were involved in shaping the concept: Peabody as client, dn&co as the branding agency, Concilio Consult’s internal team and representatives from the Greater London Authority. This shared decision-making, combined with early validation rounds, helped us avoid endless revisions and last-minute surprises, ensuring that the final outcome matched the client’s expectations and the needs of the community.
DAGENHAM.COLLABORATE_WITH_PURPOSE_DESCRIPTION: My main contribution focused on the design of the website and a wide range of printed materials, including signage and public information leaflets. Using dn&co’s visual guidelines as a foundation, I adapted the brand into an accessible, intuitive and cohesive experience. The audience for this project was incredibly diverse in age, background and digital literacy, so accessibility played a central role. The aim was to deliver clarity without losing the bold and colourful spirit of the brand. My previous experience working with public institutions, and particularly with Peabody, helped anticipate technical challenges and deliver on tight deadlines. My background in large-format print also ensured that all materials translated effectively from screen to physical environments.
DAGENHAM.PRIDE_AND_MEMORY_DESCRIPTION: Thanks to the new collaborative workflow, the design process started with active listening and a real understanding of the site’s cultural context. Conversations with residents highlighted the historical significance of the land: its industrial roots along the Thames, the iconic Ford factory that produced more than 10 million cars since 1931, and, most importantly, its place in the history of labour rights and women’s equality following the 1968 sewing machinists’ strike. Embedding this legacy into the visual design gave the project depth and authenticity. It allowed us to create a narrative rooted in community pride and collective memory, not just a new neighbourhood, but the next chapter of a place with a powerful past.

CARD.TITLE: BARKERS OF KENSINGTON
CARD.DESCRIPTION: Visual identity, web design and graphic design

BARKERS_OF_KENSINGTON.DESCRIPTION: Barkers of Kensington is a historic London landmark currently undergoing a full refurbishment to meet modern sustainability standards, while preserving its architectural and cultural value. The building will primarily house spacious, light-filled offices, and its large roof terrace overlooking Kensington is set to become one of its most striking features. To create an open conversation with local residents throughout the process, Concilio organised a series of community engagement events, which required a distinct visual identity for the project.
BARKERS_OF_KENSINGTON.STORIES_THAT_LEAD_DESCRIPTION: This was one of the most emblematic projects developed by Concilio Create. Barkers is a building with deep emotional resonance in the neighbourhood and a strong architectural presence in the city. Its symbolic weight meant that the visual identity had to feel respectful, sophisticated and firmly grounded in the history of the site. Any branding proposal needed to match both the grandeur of the building and the expectations of a community that views it as part of its collective memory.
BARKERS_OF_KENSINGTON.GOOD_DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: The final identity balanced classical visual references — paying tribute to the building’s heritage — with a contemporary and functional graphic approach. This allowed the brand to communicate elegance and seriousness without feeling outdated. The visual language was applied consistently across printed and digital materials, creating a unified presence throughout the consultation process. As part of a broader end-to-end service that included community communication and web development, the identity contributed to a strong and coherent narrative for the project. Clients highlighted the positive shift in perception, noting a more structured, professional and trustworthy image.

CARD.TITLE: +DEPORTE +MUJER (PROVINCIAL COUNCIL OF MÁLAGA)
CARD.DESCRIPTION: Visual identity, graphic design, video, photography and digital printing

DEPORTE_MUJER.DESCRIPTION: The Sports Department of the Provincial Council of Málaga is strongly committed to promoting health and wellbeing through physical activity, while challenging gender stereotypes in sport. The initiative +deporte +mujer was created to increase women’s participation across every area of sport: management, coaching, refereeing, research, training and more.
DEPORTE_MUJER.UNSTOPPABLE_IDEA_DESCRIPTION: What began as a short-term institutional campaign across the province quickly became an ongoing project due to its positive impact. The main objective was to make women visible in sport, normalise their presence, celebrate their achievements and promote genuine equality without falling into clichés or stereotypes. During the three years I was part of the team, more than twenty activities and sponsorships were carried out, including the +deporte +mujer Week, with daily actions such as guided hikes led by women ambassadors and walking events for older participants.
DEPORTE_MUJER.KEY_CHALLENGES_DESCRIPTION:
The main challenge was to create a visual identity that broke away from a traditional institutional tone. The campaign needed to feel friendly, energetic and adaptable to a wide range of physical and digital formats. As the lead designer for print applications, I developed a versatile graphic system centred around a handwritten, energetic logotype designed to convey movement and vitality. We selected vibrant, almost neon colours against a black background to ensure strong contrast and high visibility. The idea was for participants to feel that the campaign spoke to them directly, rather than as something distant or imposed.

One of the most important challenges was translating the brand into physical space. Traditional materials such as roll-ups proved impractical for outdoor activities, so I designed a lightweight circular display, affectionately nicknamed the cookie, that was easy to transport and highly visible. It quickly became a recognisable feature of the campaign, especially at open-air events.
DEPORTE_MUJER.DESIGN_WITH_MEANING_DESCRIPTION: One of the most important challenges was translating the brand into physical space. Traditional materials such as roll-ups proved impractical for outdoor activities, so I designed a lightweight circular display, affectionately nicknamed the cookie, that was easy to transport and highly visible. It quickly became a recognisable feature of the campaign, especially at open-air events.
DEPORTE_MUJER.TANGIBLE_IMPACT_DESCRIPTION:
The visual identity had an immediate effect on recognition and engagement. Participants of all ages commented on the appeal of the logo. Promotional T-shirts, for example, became everyday clothing rather than a typical piece of campaign merchandise, reinforcing the sense of belonging and pride.

With a cohesive visual language and an accessible yet professional tone, the campaign strengthened its presence across the province. Several years later, +deporte +mujer remains active, and its visual identity continues to play a key role in maintaining a close connection with the community.

COMMON.SERVICES: REBRANDING, UI/UX DESIGN, GRAPHIC DESIGN AND MOTION GRAPHICS
